results.title: Gases and how they combine
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Chemical Education Material Study Series”.
Provides experimental evidence for Avogadro’s Hypothesis. First, some properties that distinguish gases are shown. Then, the volume of ammonia and hydrogen chloride that combine are measured quantitatively. The volume ratio is found to be 1:1. In a similar way, simple integer volume ratios are measured for the combination of hydrogen and oxygen, of nitric oxide and oxygen, and of hydrogen and chlorine. These simple integer ratios lead, logically, to Avogadro’s Hypothesis.

results.title: Gas welding equipment
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Gas Welding”.
Part one of a series of nine short instructional films showing methods for oxyacetylene welding from setting-up procedures through flame adjustments. Shows types of welds, cutting methods and closing down procedures. Close-up viewing of the equipment and materials being worked gives the learner an operator’s perspective into the art of oxyacetylene welding.

results.title: The Gas turbine
results.creator_credit: Peter De Normanville and Shell Film Unit
results.brief_description: The gas turbine is a heat engine, the simplest and smoothest running yet devised. All heat engines burn fuel, change a small part of the heat produced into energy, and waste the rest through the exhaust. In the gas turbine, rushing torrent of hot high-pressure exhaust gas is the turbine’s source of power.

results.title: Gas: the magic flame
results.brief_description: Use of gas for domestic purposes and in heavy industry; heating, cooking and hot water systems; variety of uses in industry, gas flame used for fusing television tubes, glass blowing, mass producing moulded glassware and light globes. In heavy industry gas heat is used in smelters at steelworks, the manufacture of hot water systems, wall boards and lead shot. Standards of safety are maintained by the Australian Gas Association.

results.title: Gas: natural energy
results.creator_credit: Michael Robertson, Australian Gas Light Company and Michael Robertson Film Productions
results.brief_description: An animated film which utilises felt-tipped pens and examines the pace of change, and points out that half of all the energy consumed by society has been used in the past fifty years. Narrated by Reginald Glanvill, with animation by Film Graphics P/L.

results.title: Gas from Gippsland
results.creator_credit: Roy A. Driver and Herschells Films
results.brief_description: Describes the construction of the Brown Coal Gasification Plant at Morwell in Victoria’s Latrobe Valley. The Plant is designed to use the Lurgi High Pressure Gasification process and will be immediately capable of delivering 15 million cubic feet daily. Shows the laying of the 103 mile gas pipe-line to Melbourne and the official opening of the Plant by HRH the Duke of Edinburgh in December 1956.

results.title: Gardens of Japan
results.creator_credit: Seiji Koga, Japan. Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Koga Productions
results.brief_description: Generations of culture in Japan are shown in gardens existing for hundreds of years; varying in form and expression reflecting the influence of the period in which each was built. A temple garden with thick moss and symbolic arrangement of stones; dry landscaping; extravagant and imposing gardens with beautiful lakes reflecting the mountains beyond; peaceful and harmonious settings for the buildings which were set in them.

results.title: Gardens of Japan
results.creator_credit: Japan Educational Film and Nihon Eiga Shin-sha
results.brief_description:
Some of the scenic beauty of Japan - in nature and in the highly cultivated and famous gardens in Tokyo and Kyoto; a variety of gardens which have been planned and cultivated to please both the mind and the eye, including those using sand and stone to represent natural
landscapes and which have symbolic significance. A short sequence shows the traditional tea ceremony.
